{{Marketing}} '''Precision marketing''' is a [[marketing]] technique that suggests successful marketing is to retain, [[cross-sell]] and [[upsell]] existing customers.<ref>{{cite book | last1 = Peppers| first1 = Don| last2 = Rogers| first2 = Martha| title = Managing Customer Relationship: A Strategic Framework | url = https://archive.org/details/managingcustomer0000pepp| url-access = registration| publisher = John Wiley & Sons,Inc., Hoboken | year = 2004| ISBN=978-0-47165-641-8 }}</ref>
Precision marketing emphasizes relevance as part of the technique.<ref>{{cite book | last1 = Zabin| first1 = Jeff| authorlink=Jeff Zabin|last2 = Brebach| first2 = Gresh | title = Precision Marketing: The New Rules for Attracting, Retaining and Leveraging Profitable Customers | url = https://archive.org/details/precisionmarketi00jeff| url-access = registration| publisher = John Wiley & Sons,Inc., Hoboken | year = 2004| page = [https://archive.org/details/precisionmarketi00jeff/page/47 47] | ISBN=0-471-46761-8 }}</ref> To achieve Precision Marketing, marketers solicit personal preferences directly from recipients. They also collect and analyze behavioral and [[transactional data]].<ref>Nelson, Scott. "Database Marketing, Part 1," Gartner Group Research Report, August, 1996</ref>
==Development==
The development of precision marketing coincides with the development of [[market segmentation]], advancements in technology and the customer's reaction to the proliferation of [[mass marketing]].<ref>"Why Relevance Drives Response and Relationships: Using the Power of Precision Marketing to Better Engage Customers." 2009 CMO Council</ref>
[[Jeff Zabin|Zabin]] and Brebach portray the development of market segmentation. They describe the inception of the term in the 1950s and show that with time, increasingly more information was considered relevant for marketing purposes. Market segmentation evolved from simple [[demographics]] in the 1950s to [[geodemographics]] and behavioral segmentation in the 1960s (the propensity to purchase) to [[psychographics]] data in the 1970s (personality and lifestyle), to [[customer loyalty]] and profitability in the 1990s and to economic data in current times.<ref>{{cite book | last1 = Zabin| first1 = Jeff| last2 = Brebach| first2 = Gresh | title = Precision Marketing: The New Rules for Attracting, Retaining and Leveraging Profitable Customers | url = https://archive.org/details/precisionmarketi00jeff| url-access = registration| publisher = John Wiley & Sons,Inc., Hoboken | year = 2004| pages = [https://archive.org/details/precisionmarketi00jeff/page/30 30–37] | ISBN=0-471-46761-8 }}</ref> The conceptual evolution of market segmentation is the cornerstone of precision marketing. In precision marketing, segments could be defined as narrowly as follows: full-time MBA students, married with young children, planning their next vacation.
The evolution of segmentation was supported by advancements in technology. The shift into digital enabled an easier capture and retention of data while increasingly efficient databases facilitated the usability of that data.<ref>{{cite book | last1 = Blattberg | first1 = Robert | last2 = Byung-Do | first2 = Kim | last3 = Neslin | first3 = Scott| title = Database Marketing: Analyzing and managing customers | publisher = Springer Science and Business Media, New York | year = 2008| pages = 3–10 | ISBN=978-0-387-72578-9 }}</ref> Although advancements in technology were crucial to the type of market segmentation used in precision marketing, they were not the driving force behind it. Instead, customer demand and expectation, alongside the fierce competition, were the driving factors.
Learmer and Simmons (Learmer & Simmons, 2007) determine that American consumers are overwhelmed by an avalanche of over 3000 marketing messages daily<ref>{{cite book | last1 = Learmer| first1 = Richard| last2 = Simmons| first2 = Mark| title = Get Off Your Ass and Join the Revolutio | publisher = HarperCollins Publishers, New York| year = 2007| page = 120 | ISBN=978-0-06-115110-1 }}</ref> Marketing messages increasingly penetrate the private domain both in print (direct mail and telemarketing) and in digital (emails and mobile phone). As a result, customers are becoming less receptive to unsolicited marketing communication, specifically if it is irrelevant or impersonal.<ref>{{cite book | last1 = Zabin| first1 = Jeff| last2 = Brebach| first2 = Gresh | title = Precision Marketing: The New Rules for Attracting, Retaining and Leveraging Profitable Customers | url = https://archive.org/details/precisionmarketi00jeff| url-access = registration| publisher = John Wiley & Sons,Inc., Hoboken | year = 2004| page = [https://archive.org/details/precisionmarketi00jeff/page/26 26] | ISBN=0-471-46761-8 }}</ref> This is the context that gave rise to the practice of precision marketing.
==Application==
The most common applications of precision marketing are in customer retention and revitalization. Here are a few examples for precision marketing tactics that have been used by several major companies, such as [[Best Western]]<ref name="Best Western Melds Old and New">{{cite web|url=http://www.infoprintsolutionscompany.com/internet/comnelit.nsf/Files/Response_Magazine_Reprint/$File/Response_Magazine_Reprint.pdf/ |title=Best Western Melds Old and New |publisher=InfoPrint Solutions Company}}</ref> and [[Tesco]].<ref name="Tesco's Segmentation and Modeling System">{{cite web |url=http://www.cengage.co.uk/evans/students/cases_book/06cases/06_0_tesco.pdf/ |title=Tesco's Segmentation and Modeling System |publisher=Cengage Learning |access-date=2010-12-09 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091229090754/http://www.cengage.co.uk/evans/students/cases_book/06cases/06_0_tesco.pdf |archive-date=2009-12-29 |url-status=dead }}</ref>
